column1: === World War II ===

In 1942 American GIs arrived in Bideford. At first they were there to work in radar stations across North Devon and work on experimental things. More American troops began to arrive as the war progressed. Experiments nearby
column2: including The Great Panjandrum
column3: were said to be viewed in the area in secret by Dwight D. Eisenhower and Sir Winston Churchill at the Strand Cinema. In 1943 more Americans arrived as D-day training had begun at beaches across North Devon During the war Bideford Ordnance Experimental Station Depot O-617 was set up to experiment on waterproofing equipment for the D-day landings. The Americans' GI camp was at Bowden Green in Bideford
column4: and had plenty of facilities
column5: including a cinema. There was also a vehicle repair shop off the Kingsley Road
column6: and the Pill was taken over by US forces as well. Because of the sheer number of American soldiers in the area by 1943 the American Red Cross opened a club near Chudleigh Fort in East-the-Water. Bideford had an Auxiliary Unit Patrol at Cleave Mine

During the war 2700 evacuees were expected in Bideford; a large number of these came and stayed throughout the war. During World War Two a bomb was dropped on a house in Bowden Green and caused substantial damage. Also during the war an RCAF bomber crashed in East the Water; three men were killed and one badly injured. A memorial has been put on the Tarka Trail to commemorate this. It is also thought that during the war there was an experimental Royal Navy unit testing a secret petrol pipeline in the river. It is thought that after being rescued in the Bristol Channel

column1: === Long Bridge ===

The original Long Bridge spanning the River Torridge connecting the East and West of the town was said to have been built out of timber in the year 1286. In 1474 the original structure was replaced by the masonry arch bridge seen today. The bridge was built around the timber so people could still use it while construction was taking place

column1: === Port and shipping ===
By the 16th century Bideford had become Britain's third largest port. Sir Walter Raleigh landed his first shipment of tobacco here
column2: although
column3: contrary to popular belief
column4: he was not the first to import tobacco to England. Several local roads and a hill have been named after Raleigh. Bideford was heavily involved in the transport of indentured servants to the New World colonies. Bideford also was heavily involved in the Newfoundland cod trade from the 16th century to the mid-18th century. 28 Bideford vessels with a tonnage of 3860 were involved in this practice in the year 1700. In the years 1706
column6: 1726 and 1758 fishermen of Bideford sent petitions demanding the building of a fort in Newfoundland to protect them from Native Americans and the French.  Bideford also imported large amounts of Irish wool in the 18th century.

column1: === Bideford Black ===

column3: with the black colouration created by the carbon. The seams containing Bideford Black Stretch from Hartland

column5: and onto Umberleigh. Bideford Black was used in a number of ways; for example

column7: in mascara by Max Factor
column8: by artists
column9: and in the boat-building industry. Bideford Black was processed as a paint and a dye up until the mining stopped. A number of artists (mainly local artists) used these Bideford Black paints and oils in their works. The Bideford Black Mining Company produced Biddiblack powder at a processing plant in Chapel Park

column1: === Twinning ===
The town is twinned with Landivisiau in France. It has been twinned with Landivisiau since 1976; each year members of the Bideford Twinning Association take part in an exchange trip with Landivisiau.
On 20 October 2006
column2: British ex-patriate David Riley came to mark the '20-year link' between Manteo on Roanoke Island
column3: North Carolina
column4: and Bideford. The Bideford town clerk
column5: George McLauchlan
column6: told him that locals had never heard of Manteo
column7: and that the only town Bideford was twinned with was in France. Mr Riley handed over a clock to 'celebrate' the twenty-year link
column8: while the Manteo Town manager Kermit Skinner said the link started in the 1980s during the 400th anniversary of Raleigh's voyages to America.

column1: It turns out the 'twinning' of Bideford with Manteo had been established 20 years before. But the story goes back much further – 500 years – to the mysterious disappearance of a colony of more than 100 people on Roanoke Island
column2: many of whom were immigrants from Bideford. The colony was established by Sir Richard Grenville
column3: who brought back two Native American Indians
column4: one of them called Manteo which gave the North Carolina town its name.

column1: Bideford Art School was located on The Quay from 1896 to the 1970s. Alumni included Judith Ackland and novelist Rosemary Sutcliff. Today the building houses Bideford Arts Centre. The Burton at Bideford is an art gallery and museum in the town that has collections on various things of interest connected with Bideford's heritage
column2: including clay pipes and tea caddies. The art gallery displays work by local artists featuring local heritage and local landscapes.

column1: === Bideford Film Society ===

The Bideford Film Society was set up in 2001 and with the aid of a grant from the Bridge Trust and Bideford Town Council. The Bideford Film Society shows films just after their cinema release. The films are screened at Kingsley School

column3: and consists of a large market hall which
column4: as well as markets
column5: hosts boxing matches and other events; and Butchers Row which is now made up of small shops
column6: galleries
column7: and butchers' stalls.A farmers' market takes place on the quay on nearly every Saturday throughout the summer. A continental market also visits Bideford annually – market traders from France
column8: Belgium
